say.ldquoIt is everyone and I got that point across and set up drop-in sessions so we have always got younger pupils to get involved.Similarly, Georgie, of East Linton, was keen to strengthen the schoolrsquos eco profile.She added: ldquoOne issue I would push, which the school is doing, is to make the school as eco as possible.ldquoThere is a lot of buzz around climate change.Mrs Slowther said there was a strong list of candidates for the two roles.She added: ldquoBoth Thomas and Georgie stood out with their confidence, commitment to the school and a real sense of what they wanted to bring to the school.

title: pensioner-collided-schoolchildren-outside-musselburgh-grammar-school-avoids-driving-ban
story: Ian Steedman, , had just collected two children from outside Musselburgh Grammar School when he lost control of his car and ploughed into the three teenage pupils.Steedman, of Edinburgh Road, Tranent, believed that his brakes had failed, causing him to strike the schoolchildren, but tests carried out later on his Honda Civic showed no problems with the braking system.The grandad, who owns Bisset  Steedman in Tranent, later realised he had got his foot stuck under the brake pedal, causing him to lose control of the car last November.Steedman had initially pleaded guilty to dangerous driving last month but changed his plea after seeking legal advice.He appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court today , where he admitted an amended charge of careless driving by driving through a red light and colliding with three children and a vehicle at Musselburgh on November  last year.Fiscal depute Nicole Lavelle told the court that Steedman had collected a young relative and a friend from outside the school at about .pm before making his way onto the townrsquos Inveresk Road.Ms Lavelle said: ldquoAs the accused drove he became aware he could not stop his vehicle and he consequently drove onto the opposite carriageway to avoid two vehicles which had stopped at a red light.ldquoAs the -year-old boy passed halfway across the crossing, he was struck by the accusedlsquos vehicle, lting him up on to the bonnet."The vehicle also delivered a glancing blow to two others.ldquoThe accusedrsquos vehicle continued through the crossing and collided with the front near side of a car.The fiscal said two of the school pupils who were struck were  years old and the third was .Ms Lavelle added that the boy who landed on the bonnet of Steedmanrsquos car received a large gash to his upper leg after he ldquoended up between the two vehicles when they collided.Ms Lavelle said the boy then landed on the roadway and was rushed to Edinburgh Royal Infirmary for treatment he spent the night at the hospital.Steedman subsequently had his eyes tested by police officers and the court heard he had ldquoprovided a negative breath test following the incident.Defending solicitor Mary Moultrie said that her client had taken ldquoevasive action by pulling onto the opposite carriageway after realising he could not brake in time.Ms Moultrie added that Steedman ldquobelieved his brakes had failed at the time of the collision but afterwards realised he ldquomust have put his foot under the brake pedal.The lawyer said that Steedman had had a clean driving licence for the past  years and had been driving at a ldquovery low speed when he struck the three children.Ms Moultrie added: ldquoThis a genuine one-off, isolated incident that is very regrettable.Sherf Peter McCormack agreed and sentenced Steedman to a pound fine and placed six penalty points on his driving licence.

title: efforts-tackle-climate-change-east-lothian-39-small-slow-39-says-group
story: Action group Rewilding East Lothian is calling on East Lothian Council to increase tree and wildflower planting and for unused council land to be given over to wildle.But the local authority has defended its position and highlighted ious projects which it feels are making a dference.The campaign and action group has already gained more than  members since being founded in April.It has called on the council to adopt a lsquoRewilding Motionrsquo which could lead to a number of steps being taken, including reduced mowing and spraying of green spaces.Helen Carlyle, a group member from North Berwick, said: ldquoWe live in a beautul part of Scotland but our childrenrsquos futures are under threat.ldquoThe human race depends on bees and other pollinators and those creatures need wildflowers and weeds to live in. One way we can fight back against ecological collapse is to have wilder, unmown, unsprayed spaces around us. Short grass and manicured parks may look neat but itrsquos vital to have flourishing wild spaces too.Rewilding East Lothian wants the council to commit to planting thousands more trees to help absorb the carbon dioxide emissions that are driving global warming.In addition, the council has been challenged to radically reduce mowing and weed-killing, since weeds provide homes for bees and other pollinators, and to mitigate the loss of green spaces to housing by proactively making dedicated areas for nature to flourish.A council spokeswoman said East Lothianrsquos reputation as the Garden County was ldquoappreciated by residents and visitors alike. She pointed to the relaxation in the cutting of greenspaces and the use of plant species which attract a wide range of pollinators. She added: ldquoOur most recent residentsrsquo survey found high levels of satisfaction with our parks, gardens and open spaces.ldquoWe have a number of initiatives to increase sustainable management of our countryside sites and improve bioersity and pollination.ldquoThis is reflected in the work we have been doing with partners such as Buglersquos John Muir Pollinator Way project, the planting of , metres sqaure of wildflower meadow, low impact grassland management and targeted use of a weedkiller where appropriate.ldquoOur Green Network Strategy, part of our Local Development Plan, recognises the importance of vacant and derelict land for wildle, and seeks to identy suitable locations for tree planting given the important role that trees play in mitigating climate change. This links in with the draft Climate Change Strategy which considers in more detail how East Lothian can tackle climate change.

title: bid-cockenzie-pub-39-s-beer-garden-open-longer
story: The Thorntree Inn in Cockenzie has to close its beer garden at pm as part of its planning conditions.However, agents for the pub owners Caledonian Heritable argue that the beer garden, which overlooks the Firth of Forth, has become a popular destination in itself and is unfairly disadvantaged by the fact it has to close at the early time.And they say the closure has put severe limits on the use of the popular spot in the village by its customers.The pub is thought to be one of the oldest in East Lothian, opening its doors as Barclays Hotel in .It opened the beer garden, which runs along the bottom of neighbouring gardens and overlooks the seafront, five years ago.Applying for a change in the conditions to allow it to stay open until pm in the evenings, the agents said: ldquoAs drinking habits have changed and drinking has become more sociable, it is not uncommon for beer gardens to be destinations in their own right.ldquoThis beer garden in question has excellent views across the Forth and affords a relaxed atmosphere for friends and families to enjoy time together.They said that the beer garden had run without complaints and listed a number of other beer gardens across East Lothian that are open until pm.They said: ldquoClosing the beer garden at pm is having a detrimental effect on the business and is resulting in disappointed customers.ldquoIt seems unreasonable given the lack of complaints and incidents regarding our clientsrsquo beer garden that it should close at pm when other beer gardens in East Lothian remain open.

title: major-review-east-lothian-schools-consider-closures
story: Fiona Robertson, East Lothian Councilrsquos head of education has revealed proposals to consult parent councils, communities and families over ways to change the current schools estate.The pre-consultation, which was given the go-ahead by councillors at a meeting this morning , will consider a ldquofull range of options.In a report to a meeting of the council, Mrs Robertson confirmed that the consultation would consider catchment reviews, new school build requirements, school merger proposals on a new site involving the closure of existing schools, and other alternative proposals put forward during the consultation.East Lothian Councilrsquos Labour administration scrapped proposals to close rural schools operating at less than  per cent capacity ahead of last yearrsquos budget after it met strong opposition.If it had been adopted, the proposal would have seen two primary schools ndash Stenton and Humbie ndash close their doors.The new review will focus mainly on primary schools and will look at the range of uses of school buildings and other council buildings by local communities.Mrs Robertson told the meeting: ldquoIt is essential we carry out this review given the current challenges to the school estate.ldquoThe focus will be primarily on primary schools and the consultation process will be about six months.Councillor Norman Hampshire, deputy leader, told the council meeting that the review would have ldquohuge financial implications.And Councillor Stuart Currie, SNP Group leader, warned that the review would spark concern among parents.He said: ldquoThe risk of offending people is pretty high when people start talking about closures.ldquoThis is a signicant piece of work.Mr Currie and fellow SNP councillor Paul McLennan called for the results of the consultation and any ldquoemerging themes to be put before the councilrsquos education committee for discussion before coming back to the council for a decision.Speaking after the meeting, Mr Currie said there were concerns that the report would bypass the education committee, which includes members outwith the council including church officials and representatives from the teachers union.He said: ldquoIt is a decision about education and should be considered by the education committee.ldquoIt will have implications for many families and needs to be debated fully before any decisions are made.ConservativeCouncillor Craig Hoy, who has joined the education committee, said: ldquoWe agree with East Lothian Council undertaking a full review of the school learning estate to ensure it is fit for the future."The Scottish Conservative Group looks forward to the findings but will always stand up for our existing network of rural primary schools. Village schools are at the centre of our rural communities and we will strongly support them.

title: Rosemary Goring  Prince Andrew must end his silence on Epstein
story: Many of us have loved ones from outwith our own DNA pool to whom we are closer than all but our dearest relatives. The world is a much better place as a result but, unlike with family, the bonds and obligations of friendship are less clear-cut. Sometimes ties wither naturally, at others, rash or destructive relationships have actively to be severed. This is an unpleasant fact of le and one that Prince Andrew is discovering belatedly to his cost.For some time now, speculation has been mounting after the publication of a photo showing the Prince walking in a New York park with his friend, the convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, who was recently found dead in a prison cell, where he awaited trial on charges of sex trafficking and conspiracy to engage in sex-trafficking.The headlines must have made the Palace shudder, their insinuations all too clear. After details of a US lawsuit mentioning him were released, a terse statement was issued distancing the Prince from historic accusations made against Epstein, and claiming that ldquoAny suggestion of impropriety with underage minors is categorically untrue.:Prince Andrew hosted Jeffrey Epstein at BalmoralClose observers of Buckingham Palace might have noticed a cloud of dust around the flagpole as the house was shaken to its foundations. When the Daily Mail published footage recently showing the Duke of York ushering a young woman out of Epsteinrsquos Manhattan apartment in , a further statement was issued. The Duke, it said, ldquodeplores the exploitation of any human being and the suggestion he would condone, participate in or encourage any such behaviour is abhorrent.Poor Prince Andrew. He is discovering what every child in the playground knows: that you are tarred and feathered with the same brush as those with whom you mix. If one of your gang throws a brick through a window, you are deemed guilty too, evenyou did nothing wrong.In the case of His Royal Highness, letrsquos put aside for a moment the suspicions his closeness to Epstein, following his release from prison, arouse. Bad enough that Andrewrsquos personal contacts are so dodgy they raise serious questions about his judgement, let alone his behaviour.If nothing , these images suggest one of two things: that the Prince was a loyal chum who stuck by Epstein, despite his ruined reputation and the risk it posed to his own. Or that, living as he did in a gilded cage, removed from real le and the consequences of any stupid decisions he made, he was utterly unconcerned about the effect their friendship might have on his prospects. When you are cocooned from birth in a cradle of privilege when you are feted, indulged, and pandered to by sycophants and liggers from the minute you can shake a rattle, it must be easy to believe you are above the normal rules and standards by which society works.Meeting in the park with Epstein was, at best, decidedly odd for someone in Prince Andrewrsquos position. Going to his apartment, however, where a stone satyr presides over the front door, was simply crazy. According to police who raided the property, they seized photos of underage girls. These and the fetishist decor would have led most ordinary visitors to make a swt exit.These images of the Duke of York date from the period when he was acting as British ldquoSpecial Representative for Trade and Investment. A bespoke role for an aimless aristocrat, it gave him licence to roam the globe, meeting fat cats in rich countries and opportunistic states in the hope that some of their wealth would find its way into Britainrsquos Treasury.:In Pictures: Commonwealth leaders gather for state dinnerDuring his deployment as an envoy, Prince Andrew made ious embarrassing ldquomissteps, among them some politically unwise associations. Nothing, however, could compare with being identied as one of Epsteinrsquos cronies, after which revelation he relinquished the post.As the grapevine quivers with anticipation over other high-profile names likely to be found in Epsteinrsquos fat address book, the Dukersquos predicament is increasingly grave. He can hide behind the Palace gates and hope the storm will pass, but this is a story that has been brewing for years. Until certain questions are satisfactorily answered, as far as hersquos concerned it is far from over.Doubtless, it will go against every royal instinct, but would he not be wiser to face the cameras, do an in-depth interview, and silence ndash perhaps even charm ndash his critics  In a situation like this, where unfettered gossip is fuelling supposition, Prince Andrew surely needs to explain his connection with Epstein and help suffocate the scandal. It would, of course, be a historic move. No member of the royal dynasty has ever voluntarily gone on record to put their side of a wildfire story, with the exception of Princess Diana. In her unforgettable, kohl-eyed interview with Martin Bashir, she was more focused on scoring points against Prince Charles than in illuminating her own often dubious actions.Sticklers for Palace protocol might feel sick at the thought of Prince Andrew going public. Even in the hands of the most measured journalist ndash Kirsty Wark, say, or Fiona Bruce ndash it would be viewed as stepping into the lionrsquos den, a suicidally reckless act. Added to which, the Windsors do not explain. They take a long view, recognising that the passage of time usually allows even the most unsavoury episodes to fade into oblivion.In this instance, however, that seems unlikely. So what is worse  Staying schtum, and waiting for more seedy revelations to be added to the blaze, or allowing the Duke to get ahead of the story, and give his version of events By remaining aloof, the Palacersquos response suggests it hopes to avoid further fallout. The implication of this is all too plain: royals might not be above the law, but its arm would have to be very long indeed to winkle one of them out of the front door and into a Black Maria. Inviting a Windsor to a police interview, let alone into a courtroom, would require Herculean effort, and a mountain of cast-iron evidence. By contrast,Andrew were willing to face, refute and defuse the rumours, it would be an act of bravery to restore family pride.

title: theatre-review-crocodile-rock-oran-mor-glasgow-four-stars
story: Crocodile RockOran Mor, GlasgowMary Brennanfour starsA Play, a Pie and a Pint is still in the mood to celebrate  productions since its inception, so some previous successes are in the autumn roster alongside new scripts. Itrsquos one of these, Crocodile Rock, that kickstarts the season.The Crocodile Rock in question is the brightly painted landmark thatrsquos popular with tourists visiting the town of Millport on Cumbrae. For Steven ndash aged , in  ndash therersquos not much  thatrsquos eye-catching, or attractive, on his personal horizons: hersquos bored, and unsure of who he really is.He already knows he doesnrsquot fit in ndash not with any of his classmates, nor with the locals who drink in his dadrsquos pub. Inheriting that business ndash or indeed his mumrsquos BB ndash gives him the full-on heebies. Is there to be no escape for a shy, warm-hearted lad who craves a feel-good niche he can call his own As soon as Darren Brownlie arrives on-stage as Steven,and announces that this is going to be HIS story, wersquore totally onside with him. Itrsquos Brownliersquos affable twinkle, the little nod towards camperie that charms us so. That nod will acquire a wink, a shimmy and a a-tastic flamboyance as the piece progresses.This is all to the good because writer composer and directorAndy McGregorrsquos one-man musical about coming of age, coming out and coming into your own skin, has dips in its own energies ndash and Brownliersquos ability to play a iety of distinctive characterswhile singing and going into a sassy strut, counterpoints a short-fall in melodic lsquobigrsquo moments. For Steven, the le-changing encounter is with a larger-than-le drag queen.The dialogue between them ndash Brownlie switching superbly between voices and personalities ndash is the lsquoopen sesamersquo that unlocks the buttoned-up inner Steven. Gavin Whitworth and Gary Cameron are the dab hands as versatile backing musicians in what is a tour-de-force by Brownlie.

title: south-scotland-welcomes-1m-tourism-boost
story: Ministers said the South of Scotland Economic Partnershiphas awarded a total of pound,, to five projects ndash including a scheme to improve Galashiels town centre.Rural Economy Secretary title: letters-equal-status-crucial-independence-negotiations
story: There are many ways to achieve that,bearing in mind such factors as the present state assets and liabilities, the national debt, the effect of Westminster policies over the past few decades and so on.The idea that Scotland would have to walk off with, for example, a budget deficit of seven per cent of GDP compared to Englandrsquos one per cent, without there being in place other financial compensating arrangements, some which may be spread over some years, is naiumlve nonsense, and the sooner we stop discussing it in those terms the better.Scotland will be well placed to make sure that a lsquogoodrsquo deal is achieved, and it is time we looked at this matter through that equal status prism.Nick Dekker,Cumbernauld:SNP boss faces sack after independence referendum Plan B blockedWHEN Peter A. Russellclaimed that a letter from European Commission official Viviane Reding defined an independent Scotlandrsquos position in Europe I chose to ignore it. However his subsequent insistence that being on official paper meant it was the definitive legal position of the EU left me with no choice but to intervene and correct him .I now note that despite this he still seems to be maintaining his stance that Ms Redingrsquos letter is still ldquothe best available information on the issue. This appears to be on the basis that Alex Salmondrsquos contrary claim is ldquounsupported by independent legal opinion . I would challenge that latter assertion.Ms Redingrsquos letter is itself unsupported by legal opinion. The situation of a member state splitting in two has not occurred in the history of the EU . So there is no legal precedent.However there is a legal precedent to support Mr Salmondrsquos case for a third country joining the EU without the requirement to go through any negotiations or any revision of the Treaties. When East Germany joined the EU in  it was deemed to be effective from the moment unication with West Germany took place. It was seen to be merely the enlargement of an existing member state with the new combined entity being called lsquoGermanyrsquo.:Neil Mackay: Where have all the big ideas on independence gone An independent Scotland would be in a similar situation, but this time as a third country formed by the reduction in size of an existing member state as opposed to enlargement. Unlike East Germany, however, it would already have met all the criteria for membership by dint of having been in the EU for  years. As such it would be unique and therefore unlike any other third country applying for membership. That is the key point.If the Commission stipulated that Scotland would require to apply for membership like all other third countries, it would have to explain to the European Court of Justice why the legal precedent established by East Germanyrsquos accession to the EU was being disapplied in this instance.By any measure this would be an extremely spurious legal argument for the Commission to advance, especially when Scotland has a stronger economy than East Germany had, was fully compliant with EU rules, and was a known and respected European country with no history of secret police involvement. Methinks the average barrack-room lawyer would simply laugh this one out of court.Robert Menzies,FalkirkTHE picture on page six of The Herald , which accompanies the item about the Peoplersquos Vote rally shows five EU flags being prominently waved. To me, this makes it abundantly clear that the only outcome that this campaign would seek would be to overturn the result of the June  referendum.Christopher W. Ide,Waterfoot, East RenfrewshireTHE SNP are up to their old tricks by barely mentioning independence in the Shetland by-election campaign.In the  general election, Nicola Sturgeon insisted the vote wasnrsquot about separatism, won a landslide - and instantly claimed a mandate for indyref. But the  general election came weeks after the SNP leader had formally demanded indyref - and she promptly lost  seats.Now cue the Shetland by-election campaign, at which the SNP are supposedly focused on opposing Brexit. Remember, Shetland voted Remain. Yet rest assured that,the SNP wins or even grows its vote share, Ms Sturgeon will enthusiastically insist that itrsquos an endorsement of her ambition to separate us from the rest of the UK.Martin Redfern, EdinburghINDEPENDENCE is all very well but sometimes an obsession with it gets in the way of everyday concerns.The Heraldrsquos reportwas depressing to read, The rising cost of living, stagnant wages and cuts in benefits are all contributing to the misery of many Scots. I think more of a focus on alleviating such distress should be at the forefront of our much-lauded SNP Governmentrsquos mind.David Brown, Glasgow

title: neil-mackay-big-ideas-independence-gone
story: There are two sides ndash Yes and No ndash but no real debate, and certainly no obvious vision. On the Yes side, nothing has substantively changed, when it comes to big ideas, since the SNP laid out its blueprint for independence in .Brexit has altered the backdrop of the constitutional debate, but apart from a decision by SNP members to support the creation of a new currency as quickly as possible after independence, which many Yes voters donrsquot agree with, therersquos been little in the way of political imagination, creativity and innovation. The plan for Citizensrsquo Assemblies was visionary but itrsquos been undermined by SNP politicisation.Thatrsquos not to say that hard work hasnrsquot been done on the nuts and bolts of independence. The SNPrsquos Growth Commission report on the finances of an independent Scotland presented some serious economic thinking, but this is not the stuff upon which visions of new nations are built, this is the stuff of the seminar room.: Neil Mackay:Irsquom a Yes voter, but Irsquom now sick and tired of my own sideThe No side is even worse. All thatrsquos heard from the No camp is the word lsquoNorsquo. Wherersquos their vision of what a Scotland remaining in the union will look like  Brexit has shown both the Tories and Labour to be intellectually bankrupt when it comes to the future of Scotland. Yoursquod get more vision walking around a darkened room with your eyes closed than you would listening to most unionist politicians in Scotland.The new co-leader of the Scottish Green Party, Lorna Slater, seems to share concerns about the level of intellectual debate around the future of Scotland. She too worries about the vision thing.Slater has identied a few problems. Firstly, the impression that the SNP ldquoowns the idea of independence. Many Yes voters donrsquot support the SNP ndash yet itrsquos the SNP which dictates most of the discussion around independence. When a monolithic, managerial party controls debate then the drain on vision wersquore experiencing is inevitable. Whatrsquos good for the SNP in terms of holding on to power isnrsquot necessarily in the best interests of independence.A resurgence of all those grassroots Yes organisations which sprung up as the first referendum approached would provide an intellectual counterweight to the SNP, and a laboratory for new ideas.Slater is also concerned that ldquomuch of the debate around independence has focused on whether or not there should be a referendum. We should be focusing on what we want an independent Scotland to look like.Shersquos right. A second referendum will happen at some stage in the relatively near future, but what really matters,you are a Yes voter, is making sure the vision for the country is in place in order to convince the people that independence is the right course of action when the time comes.Brexit has taught us hard lessons. There was no real discussion, no real vision, about what a post-Brexit Britain would look like. A national conversation needs to begin in Scotland about the kind of country we want to be after independence.What about a constitution  The monarchy  The nature of the army  Our relationship with America  A second parliamentary chamber  Our role in Europe These issues cannot be left up to the SNP. Politicians make decisions in the best interests of their party, not the country. Parties care about power not people.We need to know the substance of what wersquore voting for, rather than the intellectually bereft binary of Yes and No. The Greens are certainly setting out a clear vision for Scotland after independence. The environment will be the top priority, there will be a move away from oil and gas.Of course, the Greens also flatlined on around eight per cent of the vote during the European elections in May. However, that disappointment may account for their renewed push for a big vision for Scotland now.The Greens need to get out from under the shadow of the SNP. Being seen by voters as "the other party which also supports independence" isnrsquot a strategy, especially when Greens can provide a clear, progressive vision for the country which the SNP with its disparate factions cannot.The SNP is ready to splinter into left, right and centre the moment Scotland becomes independent. In the era of climate change, the Greens have a simple and important story to tell which other parties do not.However, honesty is the greatest storyline ndash the strongest vision ndash to present to Scotland. So letrsquos be honest. If Scotland votes Yes to independence in any future referendum, we need to accept that it is inevitable that the nation will need a confirmatory referendum on any deal negotiated with the rest of the UK regarding separation.Dr Alan Renwick, of University College Londonrsquos Constitution Unit, has raised this issue saying that a confirmatory vote would avoid the ldquoacrimony and gridlock of Brexit. He refers to the ldquograve democratic quandary where the public has not been allowed to make ldquoan informed choice about the type of Brexit the country goes through. Renwick suggests opting for a confirmatory vote might increase the turnout for Yes with the public willing to back independence in theory and then see what the politicians negotiate.A future independence referendum would be a ldquopre-legislative ballot, instructing politicians to negotiate a deal which we then vote on. That seems perfectly democratic and the kind of vision we need for this country.:Majority now want Scottish independence, says phenomenal new pollIt immediately shows a commitment to democracy over party politics, a willingness to tackle emotional and isive subjects in a collegiate way, and it projects an adult image of this nation while many other countries seem to be reverting to childhood.The First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and some of her inner circle may be publicly voicing their discomfort with the baggage that comes with the concept of nationalism of late, in an attempt to woo soft No voters, but the one thing which will change swithering minds is honestly tackling the dficulties which the journey towards independence will involve.It will not be easy - it will be hard. Admitting those dficulties is a good way to start presenting a vision of integrity and honour for a new independent Scotland.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year

title: oscar-marzaroli-man-captured-forgotten-moments-glasgow-life
story: The photograph is typical Oscar Marzaroli. Taken in , it preserves a moment asin aspic, an anonymous sliver of Glasgow le.But it wasnrsquot part of a y photo shoot. The celebrated photographer was in the city centre to photograph a student rag parade, which at the time was a busy, raucous event. It is alleged that it even featured an elephant.:Le through a lens: the unseen treasures of Oscar MarzaroliYet Marzaroli broke off to capture the quietly transfixed moment for this one shot, the only one of the child in the set of parade negatives.The same photographerrsquos famous image Castlemilk Lads  Again, he took only one.That is one of the reasons why a donation of Marzarolirsquos entire collection of negatives ndash on the th anniversary of his death ndash so excites the archivists at Glasgow Caledonian University . Nobody quite knows what it contains.He has become identied with ndash almost synonymous with ndash photographs of Glasgow in the s, not least after Deacon Blue used several of his images for single and album covers in the s. But Marzaroli worked primarily as a film-maker, making dozens of documentaries for the Highlands and Islands Development Board.His camera was ever present, however, and his photographs are now regarded by many as art.At an event at the university last night, Deacon Blue lead singer Ricky Ross launched a campaign to raise pound, to enable the entire collection to be made freely available online.The money is needed to carry out the work necessary to preserve, catalogue and digitise the images into a searchable online collection.Glasgow subway The image of the child at the bookshop window is one of  original prints, all but one developed by Marzaroli himself, to be auctioned to kick-start the fund in an event which runs until Thursday, September .Italian born, Oscar Marzaroli moved to Scotland at the age of two. He missed out on much formal education and did not go to art school as his brother had, largely as a result of childhood ill-health.He spent a year in Kingussie Sanatorium fighting TB in his late teens ndash there was doubt as to whether he would recover. Soon afterwards he was in a motorcycle accident.:Pictures of the dayldquoHe felt his whole le that he was living on borrowed time, says Marie-Claire Marzaroli, one of his three daughters. ldquoI think it gave him a kind of focus. She argues an egalitarian outlook also contributed to his ability to capture a sense of someonersquos personality.:THOSE WERE THE DAYSS: Oscar Marzaroli, Glasgows patrician with a cameraldquoHe didnrsquot like hierarchies. He would spend the same amount of time with someone, whether he was photographing a big film star or someone selling him fish.Through portraits and landscapes, he captured Scotland and its people at a time of great social change in the s, s and s. Many of his photographs of Glasgowprovide a record of signicant social change, as city slums were being cleared to make way for new social housing.The huge body of work is perhaps surprising given his untimely death on August , , at the age of .During a three-decade search for a permanent home for their fatherrsquos work, Marie-Claire and her sister Nicola say it wasnrsquot until meeting archivist Carole McCallum at GCU that they felt confident they had found a solution that satisfied them and which would have pleased him.Both teachers, they are thrilled at plans to digitise the collection and make it freely available online. ldquoIt was our motherrsquos wish we find the right setting to preserve his legacy and the family are excited by the universityrsquos plans, Marie-Claire says.There is excitement too about what might be found when the negatives are fully catalogued. While there are contact sheets in some of Marzarolirsquos files, only around , of the images have ever been printed up, and there is no certainty about what is contained in many of the negatives.Some spools of film, retrieved from his camera bag, have never even been developed. Nicola says: ldquoThere are so many images, even we do not know what treasures our dad has left hidden in thereLaunching the appeal, singer-songwriter Ross said: ldquoI got in touch with Oscar after I became fascinated with his work, and he ended up coming out with us and shooting some photographs for our first Deacon Blue album in dferent locations.ldquoIrsquod told him about the idea of Raintown and he called me one day to say there was a picture he thought suited it.St Enoch SquareldquoItrsquos the one of the sunshine coming through the clouds. We loved it and our music from that period has been linked to Oscar ever since, he said.University archivist Carole McCallum says the Marzaroli Collection is of international importance. ldquoOscarrsquos photographs are instantly recognisable ndash particularly the iconic images he took in the Gorbals before the tenements were cleared away.Theyrsquove become rooted in popular culture, but people donrsquot realise Oscar worked all over Scotland and further afield both as a photographer and filmmaker. We are tremendously excited about putting the archive online.

story: Highlands and Islands MSP John Finnie has announced he will step down at the next election after a decade in the parliament.It comes as his party, which currently has six MSPs, starts selecting candidates for .Mr Finnie, , is behind the proposed ban on smacking, which began as a private memberrsquos bill that went on to receive Scottish Government support.In the wake of this yearrsquos budget deal between the SNP and Greens, Mr Finnie has also been spearheading the proposed workplace parking levy, or parking tax.The former police officer was the first Green elected in the Highlands and Islands, winning on the list system in  and again in .He is one half of the only father and child double act at parliament - his daughter Ruth Maguire is the SNP MSP for Cunninghame South.He said: ldquoIt is an honour to serve the Highlands and Islands in the Scottish Parliament and I intend continuing to work hard until my last day in office.ldquoIrsquove been involved in representative politics since being elected a Highland Councillor in  and enjoyed helping people, but I feel the time is right to step aside and let others bring their energy and ideas to what is a demanding job.ldquoThroughout my time in Parliament, Irsquove put my home region of the Highlands and Islands and my constituents at the forefront of my work. Driven by my interest in social and environmental justice, I have been pleased to secure a number of concessions and legislative changes to improve the lives of people in the region.ldquoAt this time, Irsquom focused on working with others to secure the passage of my Memberrsquos Bill giving children equal protection from assault and hope to see it become law in the near future.ldquoThe Climate Emergency our planet is facing means that, more than ever, Green policies are required. title: chancellor-sajid-javid-fuels-election-speculation-rescheduling-keynote-speech-fast-tracking-spending-review
story: The Chancellor, therefore, could lay out the UK Governmentrsquos spending priorities for the months ahead as early as next week. Labour accused him of panicking.Mr Javid was due to make his first keynote speech as the Treasury chief in Birmingham on Wednesday but his department said it was being rescheduled.A spokesman explained: ldquoThe forthcoming spending round will instead be brought forward in early September and will cover the themes and priorities he was due to outline."By bringing his review forward, it affords the Chancellor the opportunity to unveil a series of eye-catching spending pledges, which could provide the basis for a Conservative election campaign in October or November.It will enable him to include Boris Johnsonrsquos summer spending announcements into the   budgets such as the Prime Ministerrsquos promise of , extra police officers for south of the border.Earlier this month, Mr Javid announced his "fast-tracked" one-year spending review, replacing the traditional three-year one.It is due to take place under the previous governmentrsquos fiscal rules, which have targeted a two per cent deficit in   and debt falling as a share of national income.At the time, the Chancellor said: "We will get Brexit done by October  and put our country on the road to a brighter future. The Prime Minister and I have asked for a fast-tracked spending round for September to set departmental budgets for next year."This will clear the ground ahead of Brexit while delivering on peoplersquos priorities."But Labourrsquos John McDonnell said: "Sajid Javid is getting a record of announcing events and initiatives and then within hours cancelling or reversing them."This doesnt inspire confidence. Panic seems to be setting in inside government," added the Shadow Chancellor.The spending round will cover day-to-day department budgets for   rather than a three-year period first mooted by the previous government, as the UK prepares to leave the EU on October .Mr Javid will later use the Autumn Budget to set out his views on fiscal rules and set longer-term policies on public spending and tax rates.

title: scotlands-first-community-owned-school-officially-opened
story: Strontian Primary School, on the Ardnamurchan peninsula in the Highlands, was built after the community of around  people rejected Highland Councils plans to improve their old primary school building.Community members raised around pound, towards the project, with cash coming from the community-owned hydro scheme as well as local donations.The school building was jointly funded by a commercial loan from Triodos Bank, a payment for tenants works from Highland Council, a community share offer which raised more than pound,, and pound, in grants from the Scottish Land Fund and Foundation Scotland.Deputy First Minister John Swinney said: "It gives me great pleasure to open the first school in Scotland to be developed through a community ownership model."The innovative work of parents and the wider Strontian community, alongside construction companies and Highland Council, has given local young people a fit-for-purpose school they can be proud of for years to come."Kate Forbes, MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch, said: "The opening of a new school is an exciting day for any community, but this is even more special because it is the community who built it."I know that it has not been easy or pain-free but this is an incredible day for Strontian and the surrounding areas. The new school is a great facility for the young people of the peninsula."I am delighted that the Deputy First Minister of Scotland came to formally open the school, in recognition that this is not just an important day for the Highlands but indeed for all of Scotland."Jamie McIntyre, chairman of Strontian Community School Building Ltd, said the community is "delighted" with the new school and thanked all those who made it possible.He added: "The end result exceeds our expectations and is a real asset for our community which will help retain and attract young families."It has been a challenging undertaking for our community. Hopefully our experience will make it easier for other communities to progress similar projects of their own."

title: great-british-bake-off-series-10-episode-one
story: The Great British Bake OffChannel  ****WE donrsquot have trains that run on time and World Cup qualication remains a distant memory, butthere is ever a contest for kitchen mishaps,Scotlandis in with a shout.That was one takeaway from The Great British Bake Off, which began its tenth season last night. Can it only be two years ago when it seemed the world was about to end because Bake Off had left BBC, the dependable Victoria Sponge of broadcasting, for those fondant fancies at Channel   And here we are again, watching folk baking cakes while the Amazon burns.Most of the bakerrsquos dozen of contestants were tender in years, with one chap so young his voice broke during the showstopper round. At the other end of the age spectrum was Phil, , an HGV driver, and in the middle stood a vet, a student, a fashion designer, a teacher, and a motley crew of other well-scrubbed, chirpy types. At this stage in the game their characters remain an eggy blur.One standout was the representative for Scotland, Michael,  . Michael was born in Newcastle and lives in Stratford-upon-Avon where he is a theatre manager fitness instructor. He considers himself Scottish because the family moved to Sconewhen he was seven and he studied in Edinburgh. Welcome aboard, mate.: GBBO shows no sign of turning into stodgeBefore we got to the first challenge, making a fruitcake, judges Paul Hollywood and Prue Leith, and presenters Sandi Toksvig and Noel Fielding, did the now traditional opening skit. They opted for the Wizard of Oz, which involved Noel, as Dorothy, wearing a gingham dress. Sandi asked, ldquoIs it weird I fancy you now  Paul chipped in: ldquoSo do I. Paul, as you may have read in the papers, is currently going through a messy orce and a split from his younger lover. He is bearing up remarkably well. Must be all that sugar.Michael, in honour of his Scottish Indian heritage, was making a ldquoCup of Chai fruitcake. His mum had texted him at am that day to tell him to ldquoBe calm, be slow, and be confident. Wise words, to which every other mother, having seen Michael chop fruit with giddy abandon, added: ldquoAND BE CAREFUL WITH THAT BLOODY KNIFE! Sure enough, he cut himself. His fingers were already covered in plasters. ldquoThis has to be the last one, he sighed, ldquoI donrsquot have any left. Whether he was talking about fingers or plasters it was not clear. By episode three we can expect a nationwide call for blood donors.On we cantered to the technical challenge, angel cake slices, which had to be made according to Pruersquos -stage recipe. If your instinct on hearing the phrase ldquo-stage recipe is to drive to the nearest petrol station for a Battenberg, applying to take part in Bake Off probably isnrsquot for you.: The Bake Off effectIn keeping with the showrsquos naughty but nice traditions there were several servings of double entendre with whipped filth on top, as when Paul thought one contestant was going to make a furry garden rather than a fairy one for her showstopper birthday cake. ldquoHow big is your furry garden  he giggled. Steady on, fella, yoursquore in enough hot water.There were some calamities, but only minor ones like forgetting to switch a timer on. We hope for bigger, better, worse, in the nine weeks to come. As for who was named star baker and who was given their marching orders I cannot oblige, because TV reviewers are not trusted with the final seconds. Asanyone would be daft enough to give the game away, eh Prue  Whoever triumphed, Irsquoll bet victory was sweet.

title: bbc-take-alexa-launch-voice-assistant
story: The new system, called Beeb, will be built into the BBCrsquos website and iPlayer on smart TVs, but will not be a standalone device such as Amazon Echo or Google Home.It will allow users to find their favourite programmes and use the BBCrsquos online services. The software will also be made available to manufacturers who want to incorporate it in their products.The BBC has pledged to make sure the system understands regional accents by asking office staff around the UK to record their voices to ldquotrain the software.US-developed voice assistants famously do not cope well with regional accents, with videos of people getting into comical arguments with smart assistants not understanding their accents going viral online.A study also found . per cent of Scots said they were frustrated when speaking to systems such as Alexa and Siri.People are also likely to drop their accentsaltogether when speaking to systems such as Alexa or Siri for fear of not being understood, according to a survey conducted in Newcastle.The BBCrsquos voice assistant will be activatedby saying the word ldquoBeeb, but some analysts are sceptical over the reliability of the word.Ben Wood, from CCS Insight, told the BBC:ldquoTypically, voice assistants use a multi-syllable word or phrase such as Alexa or Hey Google to ensure accurate identication. I fear Beeb might end up being unreliable.The BBC replied the word worked well during research, but it was not a final decision.Beeb is developed by the BBCrsquos own team, so it will not present users with the broad range of services offered by Alexa or Siri, which are made by major technology companies. Mr Wood told the BBC it would be dficult for the public broadcaster to compete with the tech giants.Voice assistants have become a common feature in British homes, as one-fth of UK households now own a smart speaker.Beyond offering users from around the UK the ability to use a voice assistant without the need to drop their accent, Beeb is intended to give the BBC more independence, in particular to collect userrsquos data. The BBC will withdraw its radio stations from the popular InTune app, which is used by Alexa, after Amazon refused to share user data with the Corporation.The BBC told : ldquoWith an assistant of its own, the BBC will have the freedom toexperiment with new programmes, features and experiences without someone rsquos permission to build it in a certain way. It will also allow the BBC to be much more ambitious in the content and features that listeners can enjoy.The BBC said it is also aware of usersrsquo concerns with commercial voice assistants and their use of their data.The broadcaster said: ldquoPeople know and trust the BBC, so it will use its role as public service innovator in technology to ensure everyone ndash not just thetech-elite ndash can benefit from accessing content and new experiences in this new way.In the UK, an estimated . million Britons use a smart speaker at least once a month, or theequivalent of .% of internet users, according to data by emarketer. Amazon currently beats competitors as the biggest smart speaker providerin Britain, with a market share of .%. Googlehas .%.Globally, Amazon dominates the smart speaker market with .% market share in the secondquarter of , according to a report by Canalys. Newcomer Chinese-owned Baidu comes second at .%, and Google third at .%.Scots facing issues with voice recognition have been a comedy topic for years. In , a clip in sketch show Burnistoun showing two Scots unsuccessfully trying to talk to an elevator, became an internet favourite. Two years ago, the firstGlaswegian voice assistant, ldquoSenga, appeared in show Gted and Gallus on BBC Scotland.

title: citizen-science-activists-target-salmon-farms
story: Environmental and animal welfare groups are to carry out their own tests on the public waters around salmon farms, as they call for the industry to address fears over disease and animal welfare issues.The peaceful protest follows a,-name petition calling onthe Scottish Government to make emergency inspections of salmon farms.Don Stanord, director of environmental campaign group Scottish Salmon Watch, which is coordinating a nationwide citizen science action plan at farms around the Scottish coast, said: ldquoThe Oban area will be the first one this weekend. We will leave Dunstaffnage Marina, outside Oban, with people swimming and in kayaks and we will be sampling effluent across salmon farm cages.ldquoWe will sample the effluent around salmon farms and conduct some citizen science.He claimed: ldquoOver  per cent of farmed salmon tested by the Scottish Government have got a virus and will have all kinds of toxic waste.ldquoOne-fth to one-quarter of all farmed salmon are dying every year. If this was happening on land there would be outrage. Itrsquos a case of out of sight, outof mind.Mr Stanord says the police and salmon farm companies have been notied that activists will begin their plan by circling salmon feedlots around Norwegian owned Mowi and Scottish Sea Farms at their sites in the Firth of Lorn, Sound of Jura and Loch Linnhe.Protesters will wear fancy dress, with outfits including a lobster in a gas mask, a salmon, a harbour porpoise in ear defenders and a seal in bullet proof vest being used to highlight their cause.Sondhya Gupta, of campaign group SumofUs, said: ldquoTherersquos a rising tide of pubic opposition to Scottish salmon farmsrsquo dirty business.ldquoScottish salmon should be the pride of Scotland ndash not a shameful secret branded sustainable while fish live in filthy conditions, unfit for any animal.ldquoThis year, over , SumofUs members called for the Scottish Government to force emergency inspections of salmon farms.ldquoWhile [there is a] delay, wersquore stepping in ndash but as some point regulators need to do their own job.Animal Concern group spokesman John Robins said it was time for people to reclaim the seas from floating fish farms, which are polluting the nationrsquos coastal waters, destroying wildle and turning the king of fish into the equivalent of battery hens.He claimed: ldquoSalmon farming is unsustainable, incredibly cruel and very damaging for the marine environment.ldquoThe Scottish Government must take the lead from protesters and act now to stop salmon farmers destroying our coastal ecosystem.Aquaculture has become crucial to Scotland in helping to sustain economic growth in rural and coastal communities, particularly in the north and west.It is a erse sector that takes in the farming of both finfish ndash dominated by the production of Atlantic salmon ndash and shellfish species, such as mussels and Pacic oysters.The Scottish Government supporteda working group that launched the strategy to boost the value of Scottish aquaculture from pound. billion in  to pound.bn by .There was also a desire to see the number of jobs double to , over the same period.But those ambitions have taken a hit with growing concerns over fish welfare standards.At the centre of the debate is salmonndashthe largest component of the Scottish aquaculture industry, with about , tonnes produced on farmseach year.It is Scotlandrsquos single biggest food export and worth pound million.The industry says that  per cent of Scottish salmon are certied to the RSPCA Farm Assured scheme ndash a higher percentage than any other UK farming sector.But last year, the salmon farming industry came under fire for ldquoshocking levels of fish deaths as it emerged they hit record levels due to diseases and parasites.Sea lice, which have been a major problem for the farmed salmon industry, feed on the skin and blood of salmon, and can weaken the health of a fish and stunt its growth.There is further concern about non-native rainbow trout escaping from farm cages with the ability to out compete with native species and preying on juvenile populations.While the sector spends around pound million per year in research and more than poundm in new equipment and techniques to understand and manage health and environmental problems, it emerged in April levels of wild salmon in Scotland are at their lowest since records began.At the end of , the last Scottish wild salmon netting station closed because there were so few fish to catch. As a result, Scottish wild salmon is now off the menu.Following the Saturday and Sunday protests around Oban, representativesof Salmon Watch will visit the Scottish Parliament and Marine Scotland on Monday.Hamish Macdonell, director of strategic engagement for the Scottish Salmon Producersrsquo Organisation said: ldquoUnauthorised visits to fish farms place employees and the animals they carefor at risk.ldquoThey also pose serious hazards to those entering the farms without permission.ldquoAs a result, any visit must be undertaken in accordance with the strict safety and biosecurity measures in place on each farm and take place only with the express permission of the farm manager.ldquoSalmon farmers ask that people remain a safe distance away from farms and other facilities, for the safety of all involved and to protect the health and welfare of thelivestock.

title: jim-gallagher-britain-needs-new-type-progressive-federalism
story: Prof Gallagher was Whitehallrsquos most senior civil servant concerned with devolution, working as the Director-General for Devolution in the Cabinet Office, the No  Policy Unit and Ministry of Justice.He retired in June  and is now an academic heavily involved in the Scottish constitutional question and a director in the commercial and charitable sectors.In , he was appointed Visiting Professor of Government at Glasgow University and has also been a Visiting Professor in the Centre for Public and Corporate Ethics at Glasgow Caledonian University.Since , he has been a research fellow at Nuffield College in Oxford. He is co-author of England and the Union, How and Why to Answer the West Lothian Question and of Scotlandrsquos Choices, the Referendum and What Happens Afterwards.Todays world is suddenly all about nationalisms, some of them very disagreeable, as in Hungary or the US, others very disruptive, like Brexit or, potentially, Scottish nationalism. This poses a problem for many on the left who think politics isnt about achieving national sovereignty, but promoting social justice. They struggle to deal with it, and find a coherent vision of how to reconcile peoples need for identity and the demands of economic opportunity and social justice.Brexit has upset the UKrsquos constitutional applecart, and this English nationalist project has encouraged Scottish nationalism. Both projects seek to break up multinational unions in the name of sovereignty. Brexit has already split the UK down the middle, and similar vote in some future Scottish referendum would create a fissure in Scottish society that would last generations. We need something better.Whatever happens with Brexit, there is an alternative for the UK. The risks to economic opportunity and social justice presented by independence stem not from acknowledging Scottish identity, nor from increasing Scottish autonomy, but from breaking the economic and social bonds of the United Kingdom. Its domestic market is vital for Scotlands economy, and sharing resources across the UK supports social justice in Scotland through welfare and public spending programmes, as we saw again last week the latest GERS figures.We do not have to lose these benefits in order to gain more autonomy. Instead, Scotland, and the rest of the UK, should move to a more federal system. The structures of federalism, which means dferent levels of government each with their own responsibilities, can support dferent social models, but I argue for a progressive form of federalism, one designed to create the maximum scope for social justice in each part of the country. Here is what it would mean for Scotland.First of all, it implies a change of mindset in the whole UK, from the worn-out notions of parliamentary sovereignty which drive so much of our overcentralised government, especially in England, to an understanding that the UK really is a multinational state, a voluntary association of nations which come together to preserve their identities and promote their shared interests. That implies a better form of entrenchment for devolution in the UK constitution. Given the circumstances of Brexit, it means entrenching wider powers too.More important, perhaps, it implies a design which embeds the purpose of social justice in the territorial constitution. The federal UK parliament and government should be responsible for providing a guaranteed level of welfare and public service provision across the whole territory, irrespective of whether local taxable resources are big enough to support it, much as today.But government in the devolved nations should have the capacity to increase this from their own resourcesthey think it necessary. Thatrsquos an each-way bet for social justice.Wersquore already close to that for Scotland today. Not only is the Scottish Parliament responsible for most major public services, but it can supplement any welfare benefit it thinks unjustly small. It has the money too: not only is the devolved budget about  per cent per head higher than English levels, Holyrood has wide tax powers too.A UK which followed these principles would make a similar offer to the dferent regions of England. Many of those who voted Leave in the European referendum were expressing a beef with London, not Brussels: thats where they need to take back control from.Those obsessed with sovereignty and identity see nationalism as an end in itself. History tells us this is a dangerous road. But those who want to promote social justice and co-operation between dferent peoples cannot ignore the human need for acknowledgement of their identity. For them the right approach is a model of progressive federalism, empowering the UKrsquos nations and regions in a way which gives each level of government the power to promote a just society.This will be one of the themes explored by the new Think Tank Our Scottish Future being launched with an address by former PM Gordon Brown in Edinburgh this week.

title: four-go-trial-accused-trafficking-women-glasgow
story: Three men and a woman are alleged to have brought more than a dozen women from Slovakia and held them in ldquoslavery or servitude. Vojtech Gombar, , Anil Wagle, , Jana Sandorova, , and Ratislav Adam, , deny the charges against them at the High Court in Glasgow.All four, who live at ious addresses in Govanhill, have pleaded not guilty. Centring on addresses in Govanhill, it is alleged that between  and  the four conspired ldquoto commit crime of trafficking people for exploitation and trafficking in prostitution.Mr Gombar, Ms Sandorova and Mr Adam also face charges of forcing women to work as prostitutes and managing a brothel.Much of the evidence will be led from witnesses who are in Slovakia.The trial continues.

title: andrew-mckie-no-chance-stopping-no-deal-brexit
story: You donrsquot ndash whether you think Parliament is ignoring the original vote, or failing to stop an impending catastrophe ndash get a say. But Mr Corbyn, the keenest subscriber to the view that hersquos best suited to the job, was yesterday sounding out other Westminster opposition leaders. Alas, since theyrsquod settle for anyone, except Mr Corbyn, they united instead on seeking a legislative route to rule out a no-deal Brexit.Unsurprisingly, because they paint an exit with no deal as a national disaster along the lines of the Black Death or Scotlandrsquos  World Cup campaign. Yet even those people, who previously promised to implement the referendum result, thenstood on a manesto promising to implement the result, then, by one of the biggest Commons vote ever, voted to implement Article , specying ldquono deal as the default, balked at putting Mr Corbyn in power as the price of stopping any hard exit.Itrsquos dficult to see how legislation guarantees the prevention of no deal, though. Itrsquos an illogical position, when no deal is the default, and when any restrictions wouldnrsquot be binding on the PM, nor even necessarily within his gt .It is, however, no more bonkers than the Brexit Partyrsquos insistence that only a no deal Brexit is real Brexit ndash a stance no doubt inspired by government failure to deliver, but one that no one was advocating three years ago.Mr Corbyn, unlike the other party leaders, mentioned the continued possibility of a vote of no confidence. As Leader of the Opposition, hersquos best-placed to table one, but that is the extent of his advantage. Assumingit were won, the Labour leader would then have to demonstrate he had the necessary support to form a government, which means about  votes: ie, persuading some  non-Labour MPs to vote for him.The prospect of Tories, even those practically demented by the idea of no deal, backing that is nil. The Lib Dems have ruled it out. It would be a huge strategic error for the SNP. And thatrsquos before you take into consideration the fact that there could well be about  of Mr Corbynrsquos own MPs who wouldnrsquot vote for it.Mr Corbyn, despite not banging on about it in his meeting, is still apparently insisting that a vote would mean him becoming prime minister .I think a GNU would be undemocratic, undesirable and unlikely. But in a fantasy world where the proposed interim PM were Ken Clarke, or Harriet Harman, itrsquos just about possible. But you would need a vote of no confidence first. So the person best placed to bring it about is Jeremy Corbyn, and the biggest obstacle to it happening is Jeremy Corbyn.Small wonder the other leaders preferred to make it a last resort, trying instead to rule out no deal by legislation. The problem is that you canrsquot, with absolute certainty, for both practical and political reasons. Practically, because MPs have to vote for something, anything  to avoid what is otherwise the default position, and so far they canrsquot agree on what that would be. Eventhey could, therersquos no guarantee itrsquos anything thatrsquos on offer.And while the no deal absolutists are as deluded as the revoke extremists, there are potential deals ndash and the one negotiated by Theresa May is one ndash clearly even worse than no deal. Thatrsquos why MPs voted it down three times.Politically, this approach is tricky because, while Boris Johnson says he would still rather have a deal, he is totally committed to exit by October . Just as his mind wonrsquot be changed by a vote saying MPs wonrsquot accept no deal, nor will such a vote magic away the fact that itrsquos the legal default. His opponents would also have to commit to some positive course of action to replace it: either the blatantly anti-democratic nuclear option of outright revocation, or acceptance of some deal that is actually on offer at the time. Or an election.By contrast, the PM has nothing to lose by calling an election. Therersquos a sporting chance he could win itwersquove left the EU, or would do so during the campaign, or at oncehe won. Therersquos the near-certainty that the Brexit Party would prevent him winninghe were to show the slightest sign of backing down on the date.This is now a game of chicken where everyone ndash Johnson, Corbyn, Remainers, Brexit absolutists, and the EU ndash believes that their only chance of getting what they want is not to blink. The rest of us can only close our eyes and cross our fingers

title: teens-not-ones-misbehave-gigs
story: A couple of months ago, in the first throes of summer, we were quick to bemoan the army of neon-clad adolescents who descended on Glasgowrsquos TRNSMT festival, leaving a trail of glitter behind them. Loud  Yes. Using empty Lucozade bottles to disguise a half a litre of Mad Dog  Almost definitely. But, the way social media sharpened its pitchforks, you would have thought heart-shaped sunglasses were a calling card for the eventual downfall of society.All that fuss is why I find it is pertinent to point out that, after several weeks of attending massive outdoor concerts, itrsquos not young lsquouns who are the problem.It wasnrsquot a teenager who jabbed me in the back repeatedly with a selfie stick, and the woman who obnoxiously heckled Dave Grohl throughout the Foo Fighterrsquos recent Bellahouston Park gig certainly wasnrsquot born in the noughties. See also: the greying gentleman who downed a pint only to bring it back up all over the poor person in frontof him.The younger lot  They smiled, laughed and sang along, offering a cheerful ldquosorry pal whenever an overzealous dance move hit someone next to them.Rather than declaring a case of Teenagers versus the Middle Aged, I think it is important to ask: is this actually annoying, or am I just getting a bit old  For me ndash someone who is young enough to happily elbow my way to the front of a gig but old enough that my lower back will feel the effects of it the next day ndash it is a bit of both.During my recent gig adventures, I found my eyes rolling at a younger couple who spent the majority of The Curersquos two-and-a-half hour set with their tongues in each otherrsquos mouths. Then I sheepishly remembered that, only one decade earlier, I had been guilty of doing exactly the same thing. By my own admission, I am an ageing hypocrite with a short memory.Still, it remains my observation that those who claim to be older and wiser are often drunker and sloppier, as anyone forced to endure public transport the last time Take That played Glasgow will attest. The finger of blame may often be pointed at teenagers because itrsquos easy but the real anti-social behaviour is hardly limited to those under the age of .As far as Irsquom concerned, the kids are alright. Not so convinced about the parents.

title: aberdeenshire part of a new national network to save our sound heritage
story: Unique and rare recordings of Scottish traditional music made in Aberdeenshire in the s through to the s are to be preserved as part of a national initiative led by the British Library.Unlocking Our Sound Heritage is a major £. million sound preservation and access project, which has received a £. million National Lottery Heritage Fund grant.It has seen the formation of the first ever network of ten sound preservation centres, including one at the National Library of Scotland.This UK-wide partnership of institutions aims to digitally preserve half a million of the nation’s most rare and at-risk sounds and share them as widely as possible.Reel-to-reel tape recordings from the John Junner Collection - recently donated to Live Le Aberdeenshire’s Museum Service - were selected as one of the Scottish beneficiaries.The full collection comprises musical instruments, recording and playing equipment, and music recordings on wax cylinders, tapes and cassettes.Junnerwas a schoolteacher and esteemed musician from Strachan, Aberdeenshire.An acknowledged authority on the music of James Scott Skinner – Banchory’s famous dancing master, violinist, fiddler and composer – he was interested in sound, its mechanical production and reproduction on ious machines.Over the years he recorded many local musicians. His musical collecting and recordings pre-dates the Folk Revival of the s and s and consequently are unique.David Cook, sub-committee chair of Live Le Aberdeenshire, said: “We are delighted to accept this unique collection of local and national signicance into the permanentcollections of Aberdeenshire Council Museums.“Whilst the recordings are in good condition, they are threatened by physical degradation and some are stored on formats that can no longer be played. Being part of this national initiative will ensure some of our local recordings of Scots music will be digitally preserved and available to folk at home and abroad for future enjoyment and learning.”Alastair Hardie, one of the trustees acting on behalf of the late John Junner, said: “In his will, John Junner asked for his collection to be kept ‘at a suitable location in northeast Scotland’.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire Provost Bill Howatson said armed forces personnel make huge sacrices to keep us all safe"  Aberdeenshire Council achieves gold award for work with armed forces, families, veterans and cadetsviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"It is claimed the Violet Route for dualling the A could endanger Fyfe House"  Action group “appalled” at threat to Guiding house viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser""Ten years after his death, his wish has finally been fulfilled with this donation. Having the collection in the care of Aberdeenshire Council Museum Service will help to ensure the long-term wellbeing, development and accessibility of the John Junner Collection for posterity.”The major grant from the National Lottery Heritage Fund is allowing the network to develop a range of engagement activities to connect the wider public with their sound heritage. A key element of Unlocking Our Sound Heritage will be an interactive website hosted by the British Library, launching in , allowing listeners to explore a wide selection of recordings.Dr John Scally, Scotland’s National Librarian, said: “Our sound heritage is under threat as tapes, minidiscs and lacquer, vinyl and shellac discs degrade or equipment to play them becomes obsolete.“This is a vitally important project that will help to save the nation’s sounds and preserve them to be enjoyed for many generations to come.”

title: new staff support for recycling sites but permits also on the way
story: On average, % of materials taken to centres in the area are recycled, with rates ying from % to % at the ious locations. The aim is for all recycling centres to reach % by .Up to  new staff are due to be in place by mid-September and will provide advice and assistance to householders about what can be recycled. The additional roles are part of package of improvements agreed by councillors in January.However, a new permit scheme is also being introduced to move business waste away from recycling centres to create more space for new recyclable materials to improve services to householders.While most businesses pay the necessary fees to dispose of their waste and recycling responsibly, the current open access to recycling centres means some business waste is being presented as household waste so that it can be processed free of charge.To tackle this, a new permit scheme is one of the measures being introduced next year to prevent such abuse. Under the new scheme householders using commercial type vehicles - vans, pick-ups, minibuses or trailers - to take materials to recycling centres will require a permit to do so.The permits will be free of charge and can be used at any of the  recycling centres operated by the council.Households will be able to apply for the free permits in advance and a yearrsquos supplywill be issued at one time to minimise inconvenience.Permits can be applied for online or by post at any time of the year and will be valid for  months.Aberdeenshire Council does not expect the new scheme to have an impact on most householders as permits will not be required for cars, estate cars, people carriers, MPVs or xs, unless they tow a trailer or a horse box.Permits can be obtained for trailers up to  x  ft in size.Certain types of vehicle typically used by businesses will not be permitted at HRCs, specically those over . tonnes gross weight, tippers, tractors, large trailersand vehicles with twin wheels or more than four wheels.Aberdeenshire Councilrsquos Waste Manager, Ros Baxter, said: ldquoThe approval of the new permit system is very good news as it will allow us to make space for more recyclable materials at recycling centres and improve services for householders.ldquoMost households will not be affected by the permit system at all as cars, estate cars, people carriers, MPVs and xs will continue to have unlimited access to recycling centres.ldquoWe are keen to minimise inconvenience to those householders who use commercial type vehicles or trailers to take materials to recycling centres."Only one application is required to get a yearrsquos supply of permits and we have also increased the number of permits to  per year to make sure householders have enough permits to cover the grass cutting season.ldquoWe will be communicating the details of the new permit scheme over the coming months, so there will be plenty of time to apply for the permits before the new scheme starts.ldquoBusinesses will be provided an alternative service at waste transfer stations, and with a lower price for recycling, will be encouraged to segregate and recycle as much of their waste as possible.ldquoWe will be monitoring closely how the new schemes settle in and can tweak them in future based on feedback received.More information about the new recycling permit scheme is available on title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. title: final flight for flying banker
story: A Royal Bank of Scotland employee who has flown almost , trips in Orkney is celebrating retirement after  years as the UK’s only full-time ‘flying banker’.Clocking up more than , journeys on Loganair’s eight-seat Britten Norman Islander, which provides the Orkney Inter-Isle air service, Anne helped Royal Bank of Scotland customers in the isles branches.Anne served around  to  customers during each visit, from crofters to fishermen to those in the tourist industries.She is only the second person to have held this exclusive role, taking over from Maisie Muir who started the flying service in . Prior to that a banking boat, known as the Otter Bank and skippered by Anne’s great uncle, docked at each of the islands served by the bank.Officially recognised for her service, Anne was awarded an MBE in  and has worked for the bank for  years, serving customers at the branch in Kirkwall before she took on the flying banker role.Her recent farewell flight was the -minute journey from Westray to Kirkwall, piloted by long-serving Captain Colin McAllister. The aircraft was met with a water cannon salute by the airport’s fire brigade and Anne was presented with retirement gts and a Loganair membership card entitling her to two freetickets and unlimited ticket upgrades whenever she travels.As Anne left the final flight of her career she was met by Liam McArthur MSP, Bill Spence, Lord-Lieutenant of Orkney, her Kirkwall branch colleagues, Loganair and airport employees – who gave Anne a guard of honour as she walked to the terminal.Another resident of Orkney, Lois Canning, who joined Royal Bank of Scotland in  has been appointed to the role. Lois lives on the island of Shapinsay and takes the ferry to work every day. She is currently a personal banker in the Kirkwall branch.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
